Diagnosis
	1. Mixed neuroendocrine-non-neuroendocrine neoplasm (MiNEN) of pancreatic body
	Date of diagnosis
	January 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	15 Jan 2024 Diagnostic laparoscopy and biopsy

	Chemotherapy
	1. Carboplatin/Etoposide from 01-02-24 to 15-03-24 (2 cycles)
	2. CAPTEM (Capecitabine/Temozolomide) commenced 4/4/24

	Clinical studies
	Not eligible

	Current disease status
	Progressive peritoneal disease with rising Chromogranin A

	Current issues
	Worsening abdominal pain and early satiety

	Summary of consultation

I reviewed [redacted name] today who has unfortunately experienced significant clinical deterioration since our last review. The patient was initially diagnosed with a mixed neuroendocrine-non-neuroendocrine neoplasm of the pancreatic body in January 2024, confirmed on diagnostic laparoscopy. Initial treatment with Carboplatin/Etoposide was commenced in February 2024, but after two cycles, CT imaging demonstrated disease progression with new peritoneal deposits.

The decision was made to switch to CAPTEM (Capecitabine/Temozolomide) in early April, but unfortunately, the patient has continued to deteriorate clinically. Chromogranin A has risen from 250 ng/mL to 450 ng/mL over the past month. The patient reports worsening abdominal pain requiring increased opiate analgesia, and early satiety due to peritoneal disease burden. Performance status has declined from ECOG 1 to ECOG 3.

On examination today, there is marked abdominal distension with shifting dullness suggesting ascites. There is tenderness in the epigastrium and right upper quadrant. The patient appears cachectic with evident muscle wasting.

	Further investigations
	Urgent CT scan booked for next week

	Medication prescribed
	Oxycodone MR increased to 40mg BD
	Metoclopramide 10mg TDS

	Follow up
	Urgent review in 1 week with scan results
	Referral made to palliative care team

	Required GP actions
	Please monitor renal function and electrolytes
	Please titrate analgesia as needed following palliative care review
